title: EP 298 Adam Lake on Rebooting American Democracy

rawLines.text: Howdy, this is Jim Rut and this is the
Jim Rut
[Music]
show. Listeners have asked us to provide
pointers to some of the resources we
talk about on the show. We now have
links to books and articles referenced
in recent podcasts that are available on
our website. We also offer full
transcripts. Go to
jimrutshow.com. That's jimrutshow.com.
Today's guest is Adam Lake. Adam is a
social entrepreneur and experienced
founder focused on missiondriven
ventures at the intersection of
technology, ethics, and civic
engagement. He's led business
development across sectors from scaling
an organic food startup to working in
the internet industry before founding
and directing the Mosaic Foundation, a
nonprofit dedicated to humane
organizational design and systems level
social change. Welcome, Adam. All right,
great to be on the show, Jim. This
should be a good conversation. Yeah,
looking forward to talking with you
about Reboot America today, one of the
Mosaic Foundation projects. And you can
find Rebooting America at rebootingamea.
US. As I as I recall, it is re reboot
America. US reboot America. Okay. I'd
also uh point out that we've covered
some analogous territory though with a
very different focus back in EP 219 with
Katherine Gell where she had some very
specific ways about reforming the
electoral process and the congressional
process. Not nearly as big picture as
what Adam has, but it but it's relevant.
So, if you find this topic interested,
check her out. And as always, there'll
be links to all this and everything we
talk about at the episode page at
jimrutshow.com. So, uh, let's start,
Adam, with big picture. Uh, what are you
trying to accomplish with Reboot
America? What's the problem you're
trying to solve? I just want to start
back and just say that I I've been a
follower of the game B, you know,
ecosystem and your podcast for a long
time and take very seriously, you know,
this assessment that there's all these
existential threats that humanity faces,
right? the nuclear war, climate change,
you know, artificial and general
intelligence, you know, upon us. And I
feel like a sense of responsibility to
do what I can to address that and kind
of bend the arc towards a more positive
future and avoid some of the worst
outcomes in this inevitable transition
that is upon us. And it seemed to me
that writing the the ship of state, you
know, of the American experiment here
and getting us back on track would be a
significant contribution to that effort.
feels like if we have a stable United
States of America that we can better
deal with those variety of existential
threats. How do we do that? I mean, this
is an audacious concept of how can we
formulate a concept to enable a mass
movement that can turn the tide on
decades of corruption that we've seen in
the United States. We see a massive gap
between public opinion and public
policy. Do we see a two-party corporate
duopoly that's, you know, funded greatly
by the same donors and is just simply
not doing a good job representing we the
people, right? So represent us talks
about this Princeton study a lot that
says that public policy there's no zero
correlation between public policy that
the bottom 90% of income earners want
and there's a 70% correlation between
what the top 10% of income earners want
and gets passed into law. So that's
that's pretty bleak statistic and that
was back in 2014. I don't think any that
has gotten any better since. So that's
the situation we're at. I mean we could
we could talk about a lot of other
metrics of you know the state of the
union. You know we have increased wealth
and income inequality. Long story short
you know our country is in a poor state
not to mention the current
administration. So, like this is the big
question is how do we get out of this
hole we're in and what is a vision for
the future that people can rally around
that not only gets us out of the hole
but progresses us into the future. That
would be nice, right? Regular listeners
know I was involved with the no labels
movement before it kind of imploded from
being 2K Street in my professional
opinion and they were also uh thinking
about this you know that the two-party
duopoly has not delivered the goods for
the American people you know as Ralph
Nater said the uh pro-abortion procist
party and the
anti-abortion procist party so uh let's
start with some of your core problem
diagnosis
Let's go down one level. Things suck. I
think many of us will agree about that.
Let's start with how do they suck in
some detail and then we can talk about
the underlying drivers. I mean,
Katherine Gail in the politics industry,
you know, talked about this and there's
just real perverse incentives. Like
first pass the post voting like winner
take all voting is a real core problem.
You know, these two major parties, you
know, will try to appeal to their more
radical fringe base of their parties
rather than the center. And so we're
we're selecting candidates generally
speaking that don't represent the middle
and the consensus view of the American
people. Obviously, there's a campaign
finance issue starting, you know, maybe
even earlier, but as far back as Buckley
valo in 1976 that said money equals
speech and then Citizens United in 2010
that says corporations are people,
right? So, those are some of the
problems. And then, you know,
polarization has gotten worse over the
last 10 years drastically. Obviously,
social media plays a role in that. And I
do think another, like I mentioned,
wealth and income inequality is a core
issue. I'll bring up Bernie Sanders. I
think that he's been a pretty good
example. I don't want to distort this

Bernie Sanders and the progressive

what he thinks is right rather than

So, he's at least a decent example of a

new wave of principal politicians to get
elected to really change the system now.
And I bring that up because he, you

average individual would have
$250,000 more in wealth today. I mean,
that is just a dramatic change in the

I mean, imagine, you know, being able to

yes, he's always been a democratic

To come out and give a speech about it,
bad politic, you're gonna lose, dude. So
I did not back Bernie in 2020, but he is
no longer playing those silly games.
He's back to where his real strength is,
which is, you know, basic economic
populism. And I'm glad to see that.
Yeah. And even, you know, I would like
to I'm trying to encourage, you know,
the Sanders uh movement, you know, those
this fight oligarchy tour is like

how could that possibly be? And that's

and let's start with your uh your

there's a lot of core values in this

item number one. Yeah. The other
